ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned about the concept of critical theory in art as well as historical context for it. Applied close analysis and conceptual aspects centered on the 19th century which was extrapolated to contemporary times. Overall built a lot of context for art which can be applied to both the practice of art as well as viewing art.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: strengths were patricia and corey, could make more trips

Some of the contexts require a lot of historical background which I felt I lacked. This could be improved with slightly more structure and overview of some referential material, but the class itself is ambitious in scope which I appreciated. In general, the subject material is very interesting but the nature of the writing requires lots of time spent decoding and contextualizing. This makes it rewarding when you finally piece the concepts together, but additional context or brief overviews of chapters could streamline the process. The class was also smaller than usual with I think was a downside, since it would have been easier to unpack with a slightly larger group. But also with too many people, it would be hard to work through things in a meaningful way. The flexibility given for presentations was particularly nice.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.

extras.title: ART 301 02 - Critical Theory in the Studio
